utils.numerical_stability.safe_operations¶

Source: src\utils\numerical_stability\safe_operations.py

Module Overview¶

Safe mathematical operations with numerical stability guarantees.

This module implements production-grade safe operations for control systems and optimization algorithms. All functions protect against common numerical issues:

  • Division by zero: safe_divide, safe_reciprocal

  • Negative domain violations: safe_sqrt, safe_log

  • Overflow/underflow: safe_exp, safe_power

  • Numerical instability: safe_norm, safe_normalize

Mathematical Rationale: Epsilon values are chosen based on: - Double precision floating point limits (≈2.22e-16) - Control system stability margins (≈1e-12 for derivatives) - Optimization convergence criteria (≈1e-10 for gradient descent) - Physical parameter ranges in DIP system

References: - Golub & Van Loan, “Matrix Computations”, 4th ed., Ch. 2 - Higham, “Accuracy and Stability of Numerical Algorithms”, 2nd ed. - IEEE 754 floating point standard

Example: >>> import numpy as np >>> from src.utils.numerical_stability import safe_divide, safe_sqrt >>> # Protect controller division operations >>> control_gain = safe_divide(error, velocity, epsilon=1e-12) >>> # Safe normalization for optimization >>> unit_vector = safe_normalize(gradient, min_norm=1e-10)

Complete Source Code¶

  1#==========================================================================================\\\
  2#============== src/utils/numerical_stability/safe_operations.py ======================\\\
  3#==========================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""Safe mathematical operations with numerical stability guarantees.
  6
  7This module implements production-grade safe operations for control systems and
  8optimization algorithms. All functions protect against common numerical issues:
  9
 10- **Division by zero**: safe_divide, safe_reciprocal
 11- **Negative domain violations**: safe_sqrt, safe_log
 12- **Overflow/underflow**: safe_exp, safe_power
 13- **Numerical instability**: safe_norm, safe_normalize
 14
 15Mathematical Rationale:
 16    Epsilon values are chosen based on:
 17    - Double precision floating point limits (≈2.22e-16)
 18    - Control system stability margins (≈1e-12 for derivatives)
 19    - Optimization convergence criteria (≈1e-10 for gradient descent)
 20    - Physical parameter ranges in DIP system
 21
 22References:
 23    - Golub & Van Loan, "Matrix Computations", 4th ed., Ch. 2
 24    - Higham, "Accuracy and Stability of Numerical Algorithms", 2nd ed.
 25    - IEEE 754 floating point standard
 26
 27Example:
 28    >>> import numpy as np
 29    >>> from src.utils.numerical_stability import safe_divide, safe_sqrt
 30    >>> # Protect controller division operations
 31    >>> control_gain = safe_divide(error, velocity, epsilon=1e-12)
 32    >>> # Safe normalization for optimization
 33    >>> unit_vector = safe_normalize(gradient, min_norm=1e-10)
 34"""
 35
 36from typing import Union, Optional
 37import numpy as np
 38import warnings
 39
 40# Type aliases for clarity
 41NumericType = Union[float, np.ndarray]
 42
 43#==========================================================================================
 44# Constants: Epsilon Thresholds
 45#==========================================================================================
 46
 47# Division safety threshold (Issue #13)
 48# Chosen to prevent numerical instability in control law derivatives
 49# Value: 10^-12 ≈ 1000× machine epsilon for double precision
 50EPSILON_DIV: float = 1e-12
 51
 52# Square root safety threshold
 53# Protects against negative values from numerical errors
 54# Value: 10^-15 allows sqrt near zero while preventing domain errors
 55EPSILON_SQRT: float = 1e-15
 56
 57# Logarithm safety threshold
 58# Prevents log(0) and log(negative) in optimization objectives
 59# Value: 10^-15 allows log near zero with graceful handling
 60EPSILON_LOG: float = 1e-15
 61
 62# Exponential overflow protection
 63# Prevents exp(x) overflow for large x
 64# Value: 700 ≈ max safe exponent for exp() in double precision
 65EPSILON_EXP: float = 700.0
 66
 67# General small number threshold for comparisons
 68EPSILON_GENERAL: float = 1e-10
 69
 70
 71#==========================================================================================
 72# Core Safe Operations
 73#==========================================================================================
 74
 75def safe_divide(
 76    numerator: NumericType,
 77    denominator: NumericType,
 78    epsilon: float = EPSILON_DIV,
 79    fallback: float = 0.0,
 80    warn: bool = False,
 81) -> NumericType:
 82    """Safe division with epsilon threshold protection against zero division.
 83
 84    Protects against division by zero and near-zero denominators by replacing
 85    denominators with magnitude < epsilon with epsilon (preserving sign).
 86
 87    Mathematical Definition:
 88        safe_divide(a, b) = a / max(|b|, ε) * sign(b)
 89
 90    where ε is the safety threshold.
 91
 92    Args:
 93        numerator: Dividend (scalar or array)
 94        denominator: Divisor (scalar or array)
 95        epsilon: Minimum safe denominator magnitude (default: 1e-12)
 96        fallback: Value to return if denominator is exactly zero (default: 0.0)
 97        warn: Issue warning when epsilon protection triggers (default: False)
 98
 99    Returns:
100        Safe division result with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)
101
102    Raises:
103        ValueError: If epsilon is negative or zero
104
105    Example:
106        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 2.0)
107        0.5
108        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 1e-15)  # Protected division
109        1000000000000.0
110        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 0.0, fallback=np.inf)
111        inf
112        >>> safe_divide(np.array([1, 2, 3]), np.array([2, 1e-15, 4]))
113        array([5.00000000e-01, 2.00000000e+12, 7.50000000e-01])
114
115    Notes:
116        - For denominators with |b| < ε, uses sign-preserving replacement
117        - For exactly zero denominators, returns fallback value
118        - Handles scalar and array inputs via NumPy broadcasting
119        - Preserves input dtype for integer inputs (converts to float64)
120    """
121    if epsilon <= 0:
122        raise ValueError(f"Epsilon must be positive, got: {epsilon}")
123
124    # Convert to arrays for unified handling
125    num_array = np.asarray(numerator, dtype=float)
126    den_array = np.asarray(denominator, dtype=float)
127
128    # Create result array
129    result = np.zeros_like(num_array + den_array, dtype=float)  # Broadcasting
130
131    # Handle exactly zero denominators with fallback
132    zero_mask = (den_array == 0.0)
133    if np.any(zero_mask):
134        result[zero_mask] = fallback
135        if warn:
136            warnings.warn(
137                f"Division by exactly zero detected, using fallback={fallback}",
138                RuntimeWarning,
139                stacklevel=2,
140            )
141
142    # Handle near-zero denominators with epsilon protection
143    abs_den = np.abs(den_array)
144    near_zero_mask = (abs_den < epsilon) & ~zero_mask
145    safe_den = np.where(near_zero_mask, epsilon, abs_den)
146
147    # Preserve sign: safe_divide(a, b) = a / (ε * sign(b)) if |b| < ε
148    sign_den = np.sign(den_array)
149    # Handle sign(0) = 0 edge case (convert to array to support item assignment)
150    sign_den = np.atleast_1d(sign_den).copy()
151    sign_den[sign_den == 0] = 1.0
152
153    # Compute safe division (suppress numpy warnings since we handle them explicitly)
154    with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
155        result_temp = num_array / (safe_den * sign_den)
156        result = np.where(zero_mask, fallback, result_temp)
157
158    if warn and np.any(near_zero_mask):
159        num_protected = np.sum(near_zero_mask)
160        warnings.warn(
161            f"Protected {num_protected} near-zero divisions with epsilon={epsilon}",
162            RuntimeWarning,
163            stacklevel=2,
164        )
165
166    # Return scalar if inputs were scalar
167    if np.isscalar(numerator) and np.isscalar(denominator):
168        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
169    return result
170
171
172def safe_reciprocal(
173    x: NumericType,
174    epsilon: float = EPSILON_DIV,
175    fallback: float = 0.0,
176    warn: bool = False,
177) -> NumericType:
178    """Safe reciprocal (1/x) with epsilon protection.
179
180    Convenience wrapper for safe_divide(1.0, x).
181
182    Mathematical Definition:
183        safe_reciprocal(x) = 1 / max(|x|, ε) * sign(x)
184
185    Args:
186        x: Input value(s) (scalar or array)
187        epsilon: Minimum safe magnitude (default: 1e-12)
188        fallback: Value for exactly zero inputs (default: 0.0)
189        warn: Issue warnings for protected operations (default: False)
190
191    Returns:
192        Safe reciprocal with same shape as input
193
194    Example:
195        >>> safe_reciprocal(2.0)
196        0.5
197        >>> safe_reciprocal(1e-15)
198        1000000000000.0
199        >>> safe_reciprocal(np.array([1, 2, 1e-15]))
200        array([1.00000000e+00, 5.00000000e-01, 1.00000000e+12])
201    """
202    return safe_divide(1.0, x, epsilon=epsilon, fallback=fallback, warn=warn)
203

205def safe_sqrt(
206    x: NumericType,
207    min_value: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
208    warn: bool = False,
209) -> NumericType:
210    """Safe square root with negative value protection.
211
212    Clips input to [min_value, ∞) before applying sqrt to prevent domain errors
213    from numerical noise producing negative values.
214
215    Mathematical Definition:
216        safe_sqrt(x) = √(max(x, min_value))
217
218    Args:
219        x: Input value(s) (scalar or array)
220        min_value: Minimum value to clip to (default: 1e-15)
221        warn: Warn if negative values are clipped (default: False)
222
223    Returns:
224        Safe square root with same shape as input
225
226    Raises:
227        ValueError: If min_value is negative
228
229    Example:
230        >>> safe_sqrt(4.0)
231        2.0
232        >>> safe_sqrt(-0.001)  # Numerical noise
233        1e-07
234        >>> safe_sqrt(np.array([4, -1e-10, 0]))
235        array([2.0000000e+00, 1.0000000e-07, 1.0000000e-07])
236
237    Notes:
238        - Designed for control systems where sqrt(x²) may produce negative x
239        - min_value should be chosen based on expected numerical precision
240        - Use warn=True during development to detect unexpected negatives
241    """
242    if min_value < 0:
243        raise ValueError(f"min_value must be non-negative, got: {min_value}")
244
245    x_array = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
246
247    # Detect and handle negative values
248    negative_mask = x_array < 0
249    if np.any(negative_mask) and warn:
250        num_negative = np.sum(negative_mask)
251        min_negative = np.min(x_array[negative_mask])
252        warnings.warn(
253            f"Clipped {num_negative} negative values to {min_value}, "
254            f"min was {min_negative:.2e}",
255            RuntimeWarning,
256            stacklevel=2,
257        )
258
259    # Clip to safe range and compute sqrt
260    safe_x = np.maximum(x_array, min_value)
261    result = np.sqrt(safe_x)
262
263    # Return scalar if input was scalar
264    if np.isscalar(x):
265        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
266    return result
267
268
269def safe_log(
270    x: NumericType,
271    min_value: float = EPSILON_LOG,
272    warn: bool = False,
273) -> NumericType:
274    """Safe natural logarithm with zero/negative protection.
275
276    Clips input to [min_value, ∞) before applying log to prevent domain errors.
277
278    Mathematical Definition:
279        safe_log(x) = ln(max(x, min_value))
280
281    Args:
282        x: Input value(s) (scalar or array)
283        min_value: Minimum value to clip to (default: 1e-15)
284        warn: Warn if values are clipped (default: False)
285
286    Returns:
287        Safe logarithm with same shape as input
288
289    Raises:
290        ValueError: If min_value is not positive
291
292    Example:
293        >>> safe_log(np.e)
294        1.0
295        >>> safe_log(0.0)
296        -34.53877639491069
297        >>> safe_log(np.array([1, 1e-20, -0.01]))
298        array([  0.        , -34.53877639, -34.53877639])
299
300    Notes:
301        - Commonly used in optimization objective functions
302        - min_value determines the floor of log output: log(min_value)
303        - For log(0) → -∞ behavior, use min_value ≈ 1e-300 (near underflow)
304    """
305    if min_value <= 0:
306        raise ValueError(f"min_value must be positive, got: {min_value}")
307
308    x_array = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
309
310    # Detect and handle non-positive values
311    non_positive_mask = x_array <= 0
312    if np.any(non_positive_mask) and warn:
313        num_clipped = np.sum(non_positive_mask)
314        warnings.warn(
315            f"Clipped {num_clipped} non-positive values to {min_value}",
316            RuntimeWarning,
317            stacklevel=2,
318        )
319
320    # Clip to safe range and compute log
321    safe_x = np.maximum(x_array, min_value)
322    result = np.log(safe_x)
323
324    # Return scalar if input was scalar
325    if np.isscalar(x):
326        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
327    return result
328
329
330def safe_exp(
331    x: NumericType,
332    max_value: float = EPSILON_EXP,
333    warn: bool = False,
334) -> NumericType:
335    """Safe exponential with overflow protection.
336
337    Clips input to (-∞, max_value] before applying exp to prevent overflow.
338
339    Mathematical Definition:
340        safe_exp(x) = exp(min(x, max_value))
341
342    Args:
343        x: Input value(s) (scalar or array)
344        max_value: Maximum exponent value (default: 700.0)
345        warn: Warn if values are clipped (default: False)
346
347    Returns:
348        Safe exponential with same shape as input
349
350    Example:
351        >>> safe_exp(0.0)
352        1.0
353        >>> safe_exp(1000.0)  # Would overflow without protection
354        1.0142320547350045e+304
355        >>> safe_exp(np.array([-1, 0, 1000]))
356        array([3.67879441e-001, 1.00000000e+000, 1.01423205e+304])
357
358    Notes:
359        - Default max_value=700 is safe for IEEE 754 double precision
360        - exp(700) ≈ 1.01e+304, near overflow limit of 1.79e+308
361        - Underflow (exp(-x) → 0) is naturally safe and not clipped
362    """
363    x_array = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
364
365    # Detect and handle overflow-prone values
366    overflow_mask = x_array > max_value
367    if np.any(overflow_mask) and warn:
368        num_clipped = np.sum(overflow_mask)
369        max_clipped = np.max(x_array[overflow_mask])
370        warnings.warn(
371            f"Clipped {num_clipped} values to prevent overflow, "
372            f"max was {max_clipped:.2e}",
373            RuntimeWarning,
374            stacklevel=2,
375        )
376
377    # Clip to safe range and compute exp
378    safe_x = np.minimum(x_array, max_value)
379    result = np.exp(safe_x)
380
381    # Return scalar if input was scalar
382    if np.isscalar(x):
383        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
384    return result
385
386
387def safe_power(
388    base: NumericType,
389    exponent: NumericType,
390    epsilon: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
391    max_exp: float = EPSILON_EXP,
392    warn: bool = False,
393) -> NumericType:
394    """Safe exponentiation (base^exponent) with domain and overflow protection.
395
396    Handles negative bases with fractional exponents and prevents overflow.
397
398    Mathematical Definition:
399        safe_power(b, e) = sign(b) * |b|^e  for negative b
400                         = b^e              for non-negative b
401        where b is clipped to |b| ≥ epsilon and e is clipped to |e| ≤ max_exp
402
403    Args:
404        base: Base value(s) (scalar or array)
405        exponent: Exponent value(s) (scalar or array)
406        epsilon: Minimum base magnitude (default: 1e-15)
407        max_exp: Maximum exponent magnitude (default: 700.0)
408        warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)
409
410    Returns:
411        Safe power with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)
412
413    Example:
414        >>> safe_power(2.0, 3.0)
415        8.0
416        >>> safe_power(-2.0, 3.0)  # Negative base
417        -8.0
418        >>> safe_power(1e-20, 2.0)  # Small base protected
419        1e-30
420        >>> safe_power(np.array([2, -2, 1e-20]), 2.0)
421        array([4.0e+00, 4.0e+00, 1.0e-30])
422
423    Notes:
424        - Handles negative bases by: (-b)^e = sign(-b) * |b|^e
425        - Protects small bases to prevent underflow
426        - Clips large exponents to prevent overflow
427        - Use for robust polynomial and power-law calculations
428    """
429    base_array = np.asarray(base, dtype=float)
430    exp_array = np.asarray(exponent, dtype=float)
431
432    # Handle negative bases
433    abs_base = np.abs(base_array)
434    sign_base = np.sign(base_array)
435    sign_base[sign_base == 0] = 1.0  # Treat zero as positive
436
437    # Protect small bases
438    safe_base = np.maximum(abs_base, epsilon)
439
440    # Clip exponents to prevent overflow
441    safe_exp = np.clip(exp_array, -max_exp, max_exp)
442
443    # Compute power with absolute base
444    result = np.power(safe_base, safe_exp)
445
446    # Apply sign for negative bases (sign^exp pattern)
447    # For integer exponents: (-b)^n = b^n if n even, -b^n if n odd
448    # For fractional exponents: use principal value (real part)
449    is_integer_exp = np.equal(np.mod(exp_array, 1), 0)
450    is_odd_exp = np.logical_and(is_integer_exp, np.mod(exp_array, 2) != 0)
451
452    # Apply sign only for odd integer exponents
453    result = np.where(is_odd_exp, result * sign_base, result)
454
455    if warn:
456        small_base_mask = abs_base < epsilon
457        large_exp_mask = np.abs(exp_array) > max_exp
458        if np.any(small_base_mask):
459            warnings.warn(
460                f"Protected {np.sum(small_base_mask)} small bases with epsilon",
461                RuntimeWarning,
462                stacklevel=2,
463            )
464        if np.any(large_exp_mask):
465            warnings.warn(
466                f"Clipped {np.sum(large_exp_mask)} large exponents",
467                RuntimeWarning,
468                stacklevel=2,
469            )
470
471    # Return scalar if inputs were scalar
472    if np.isscalar(base) and np.isscalar(exponent):
473        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
474    return result
475
476
477def safe_norm(
478    vector: np.ndarray,
479    ord: Optional[Union[int, float, str]] = 2,
480    axis: Optional[int] = None,
481    min_norm: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
482) -> Union[float, np.ndarray]:
483    """Safe vector/matrix norm with zero-norm protection.
484
485    Computes norm with minimum threshold to prevent zero division in
486    normalization operations.
487
488    Mathematical Definition:
489        safe_norm(v) = max(||v||_p, min_norm)
490
491    where ||·||_p is the p-norm.
492
493    Args:
494        vector: Input array (vector or matrix)
495        ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean norm)
496             - 1: L1 norm (sum of absolute values)
497             - 2: L2 norm (Euclidean)
498             - np.inf: L∞ norm (maximum absolute value)
499        axis: Axis along which to compute norm (default: None = flatten)
500        min_norm: Minimum norm value (default: 1e-15)
501
502    Returns:
503        Norm value(s) with minimum threshold applied
504
505    Example:
506        >>> safe_norm(np.array([3, 4]))
507        5.0
508        >>> safe_norm(np.array([1e-20, 1e-20]))
509        1e-15
510        >>> safe_norm(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 1]]), axis=1)
511        array([1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+00])
512
513    Notes:
514        - Used to protect normalization: v / ||v|| becomes v / safe_norm(v)
515        - min_norm should match expected numerical precision of application
516        - Preserves norm semantics while preventing degenerate cases
517    """
518    norm_value = np.linalg.norm(vector, ord=ord, axis=axis)
519    return np.maximum(norm_value, min_norm)
520
521
522def safe_normalize(
523    vector: np.ndarray,
524    ord: Optional[Union[int, float, str]] = 2,
525    axis: Optional[int] = None,
526    min_norm: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
527    fallback: Optional[np.ndarray] = None,
528) -> np.ndarray:
529    """Safe vector normalization with zero-norm protection.
530
531    Normalizes vector to unit norm with protection against zero-length vectors.
532
533    Mathematical Definition:
534        safe_normalize(v) = v / max(||v||, min_norm)
535
536    Args:
537        vector: Input vector(s) to normalize
538        ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean)
539        axis: Normalization axis (default: None = flatten)
540        min_norm: Minimum norm threshold (default: 1e-15)
541        fallback: Value to return for zero vectors (default: zeros)
542
543    Returns:
544        Normalized vector with same shape as input
545
546    Example:
547        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([3, 4]))
548        array([0.6, 0.8])
549        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([0, 0]))
550        array([0., 0.])
551        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 2]]), axis=1)
552        array([[1., 0.],
553               [0., 1.]])
554
555    Notes:
556        - For zero vectors, returns fallback (default: zero vector)
557        - Use in gradient descent, direction finding, unit vector generation
558        - Preserves direction while guaranteeing unit magnitude
559    """
560    vector_array = np.asarray(vector, dtype=float)
561
562    # Compute safe norm
563    norm_value = safe_norm(vector_array, ord=ord, axis=axis, min_norm=min_norm)
564
565    # Expand norm dimensions for broadcasting if needed
566    if axis is not None and vector_array.ndim > 1:
567        norm_value = np.expand_dims(norm_value, axis=axis)
568
569    # Normalize with safe division
570    normalized = vector_array / norm_value
571
572    # Handle exactly zero vectors with fallback
573    is_zero = np.linalg.norm(vector_array, ord=ord, axis=axis) < min_norm
574    if fallback is not None and np.any(is_zero):
575        if axis is not None:
576            is_zero = np.expand_dims(is_zero, axis=axis)
577        normalized = np.where(is_zero, fallback, normalized)
578
579    return normalized
580

586def is_safe_denominator(
587    denominator: NumericType,
588    epsilon: float = EPSILON_DIV,
589) -> Union[bool, np.ndarray]:
590    """Check if denominator is safe for division (|x| >= epsilon).
591
592    Args:
593        denominator: Value(s) to check
594        epsilon: Safety threshold (default: 1e-12)
595
596    Returns:
597        Boolean or boolean array indicating safety
598
599    Example:
600        >>> is_safe_denominator(1.0)
601        True
602        >>> is_safe_denominator(1e-15)
603        False
604        >>> is_safe_denominator(np.array([1, 1e-15, -2]))
605        array([ True, False,  True])
606    """
607    den_array = np.asarray(denominator, dtype=float)
608    is_safe = np.abs(den_array) >= epsilon
609
610    if np.isscalar(denominator):
611        return bool(is_safe)
612    return is_safe

615def clip_to_safe_range(
616    x: NumericType,
617    min_value: float = -1e10,
618    max_value: float = 1e10,
619    warn: bool = False,
620) -> NumericType:
621    """Clip values to safe numerical range to prevent overflow/underflow.
622
623    Args:
624        x: Input value(s)
625        min_value: Minimum safe value (default: -1e10)
626        max_value: Maximum safe value (default: 1e10)
627        warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)
628
629    Returns:
630        Clipped values with same shape as input
631
632    Example:
633        >>> clip_to_safe_range(1e15)
634        10000000000.0
635        >>> clip_to_safe_range(np.array([-1e12, 0, 1e12]))
636        array([-1.0e+10,  0.0e+00,  1.0e+10])
637    """
638    x_array = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
639    clipped = np.clip(x_array, min_value, max_value)
640
641    if warn:
642        num_clipped = np.sum(x_array != clipped)
643        if num_clipped > 0:
644            warnings.warn(
645                f"Clipped {num_clipped} values to range [{min_value}, {max_value}]",
646                RuntimeWarning,
647                stacklevel=2,
648            )
649
650    if np.isscalar(x):
651        return float(clipped)
652    return clipped

safe_divide(numerator, denominator, epsilon, fallback, warn)¶

Safe division with epsilon threshold protection against zero division.

Protects against division by zero and near-zero denominators by replacing denominators with magnitude < epsilon with epsilon (preserving sign).

Mathematical Definition: safe_divide(a, b) = a / max(|b|, ε) * sign(b)

where ε is the safety threshold.

Args: numerator: Dividend (scalar or array) denominator: Divisor (scalar or array) epsilon: Minimum safe denominator magnitude (default: 1e-12) fallback: Value to return if denominator is exactly zero (default: 0.0) warn: Issue warning when epsilon protection triggers (default: False)

Returns: Safe division result with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)

Raises: ValueError: If epsilon is negative or zero

Example: >>> safe_divide(1.0, 2.0) 0.5 >>> safe_divide(1.0, 1e-15) # Protected division 1000000000000.0 >>> safe_divide(1.0, 0.0, fallback=np.inf) inf >>> safe_divide(np.array([1, 2, 3]), np.array([2, 1e-15, 4])) array([5.00000000e-01, 2.00000000e+12, 7.50000000e-01])

Notes: - For denominators with |b| < ε, uses sign-preserving replacement - For exactly zero denominators, returns fallback value - Handles scalar and array inputs via NumPy broadcasting - Preserves input dtype for integer inputs (converts to float64)

 3    denominator: NumericType,

12
13    Mathematical Definition:
14        safe_divide(a, b) = a / max(|b|, ε) * sign(b)
15
16    where ε is the safety threshold.
17
18    Args:
19        numerator: Dividend (scalar or array)
20        denominator: Divisor (scalar or array)
21        epsilon: Minimum safe denominator magnitude (default: 1e-12)
22        fallback: Value to return if denominator is exactly zero (default: 0.0)
23        warn: Issue warning when epsilon protection triggers (default: False)
24
25    Returns:
26        Safe division result with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)
27
28    Raises:
29        ValueError: If epsilon is negative or zero
30
31    Example:
32        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 2.0)
33        0.5
34        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 1e-15)  # Protected division
35        1000000000000.0
36        >>> safe_divide(1.0, 0.0, fallback=np.inf)
37        inf
38        >>> safe_divide(np.array([1, 2, 3]), np.array([2, 1e-15, 4]))
39        array([5.00000000e-01, 2.00000000e+12, 7.50000000e-01])
40
41    Notes:
42        - For denominators with |b| < ε, uses sign-preserving replacement
43        - For exactly zero denominators, returns fallback value
44        - Handles scalar and array inputs via NumPy broadcasting
45        - Preserves input dtype for integer inputs (converts to float64)
46    """
47    if epsilon <= 0:
48        raise ValueError(f"Epsilon must be positive, got: {epsilon}")
49
50    # Convert to arrays for unified handling
51    num_array = np.asarray(numerator, dtype=float)
52    den_array = np.asarray(denominator, dtype=float)
53
54    # Create result array
55    result = np.zeros_like(num_array + den_array, dtype=float)  # Broadcasting
56
57    # Handle exactly zero denominators with fallback
58    zero_mask = (den_array == 0.0)
59    if np.any(zero_mask):
60        result[zero_mask] = fallback
61        if warn:
62            warnings.warn(
63                f"Division by exactly zero detected, using fallback={fallback}",
64                RuntimeWarning,
65                stacklevel=2,
66            )
67
68    # Handle near-zero denominators with epsilon protection
69    abs_den = np.abs(den_array)
70    near_zero_mask = (abs_den < epsilon) & ~zero_mask
71    safe_den = np.where(near_zero_mask, epsilon, abs_den)
72
73    # Preserve sign: safe_divide(a, b) = a / (ε * sign(b)) if |b| < ε
74    sign_den = np.sign(den_array)
75    # Handle sign(0) = 0 edge case (convert to array to support item assignment)
76    sign_den = np.atleast_1d(sign_den).copy()
77    sign_den[sign_den == 0] = 1.0
78
79    # Compute safe division (suppress numpy warnings since we handle them explicitly)
80    with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
81        result_temp = num_array / (safe_den * sign_den)
82        result = np.where(zero_mask, fallback, result_temp)
83
84    if warn and np.any(near_zero_mask):
85        num_protected = np.sum(near_zero_mask)
86        warnings.warn(
87            f"Protected {num_protected} near-zero divisions with epsilon={epsilon}",
88            RuntimeWarning,
89            stacklevel=2,
90        )
91
92    # Return scalar if inputs were scalar
93    if np.isscalar(numerator) and np.isscalar(denominator):
94        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
95    return result

safe_sqrt(x, min_value, warn)¶

Safe square root with negative value protection.

Clips input to [min_value, ∞) before applying sqrt to prevent domain errors from numerical noise producing negative values.

Mathematical Definition: safe_sqrt(x) = √(max(x, min_value))

Args: x: Input value(s) (scalar or array) min_value: Minimum value to clip to (default: 1e-15) warn: Warn if negative values are clipped (default: False)

Returns: Safe square root with same shape as input

Raises: ValueError: If min_value is negative

Example: >>> safe_sqrt(4.0) 2.0 >>> safe_sqrt(-0.001) # Numerical noise 1e-07 >>> safe_sqrt(np.array([4, -1e-10, 0])) array([2.0000000e+00, 1.0000000e-07, 1.0000000e-07])

Notes: - Designed for control systems where sqrt(x²) may produce negative x - min_value should be chosen based on expected numerical precision - Use warn=True during development to detect unexpected negatives

safe_exp(x, max_value, warn)¶

Safe exponential with overflow protection.

Clips input to (-∞, max_value] before applying exp to prevent overflow.

Mathematical Definition: safe_exp(x) = exp(min(x, max_value))

Args: x: Input value(s) (scalar or array) max_value: Maximum exponent value (default: 700.0) warn: Warn if values are clipped (default: False)

Returns: Safe exponential with same shape as input

Example: >>> safe_exp(0.0) 1.0 >>> safe_exp(1000.0) # Would overflow without protection 1.0142320547350045e+304 >>> safe_exp(np.array([-1, 0, 1000])) array([3.67879441e-001, 1.00000000e+000, 1.01423205e+304])

Notes: - Default max_value=700 is safe for IEEE 754 double precision - exp(700) ≈ 1.01e+304, near overflow limit of 1.79e+308 - Underflow (exp(-x) → 0) is naturally safe and not clipped

safe_power(base, exponent, epsilon, max_exp, warn)¶

Safe exponentiation (base^exponent) with domain and overflow protection.

Handles negative bases with fractional exponents and prevents overflow.

Mathematical Definition: safe_power(b, e) = sign(b) * |b|^e for negative b = b^e for non-negative b where b is clipped to |b| ≥ epsilon and e is clipped to |e| ≤ max_exp

Args: base: Base value(s) (scalar or array) exponent: Exponent value(s) (scalar or array) epsilon: Minimum base magnitude (default: 1e-15) max_exp: Maximum exponent magnitude (default: 700.0) warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)

Returns: Safe power with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)

Example: >>> safe_power(2.0, 3.0) 8.0 >>> safe_power(-2.0, 3.0) # Negative base -8.0 >>> safe_power(1e-20, 2.0) # Small base protected 1e-30 >>> safe_power(np.array([2, -2, 1e-20]), 2.0) array([4.0e+00, 4.0e+00, 1.0e-30])

Notes: - Handles negative bases by: (-b)^e = sign(-b) * |b|^e - Protects small bases to prevent underflow - Clips large exponents to prevent overflow - Use for robust polynomial and power-law calculations

Source Code¶

 1def safe_power(
 2    base: NumericType,
 3    exponent: NumericType,
 4    epsilon: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
 5    max_exp: float = EPSILON_EXP,
 6    warn: bool = False,
 7) -> NumericType:
 8    """Safe exponentiation (base^exponent) with domain and overflow protection.
 9
10    Handles negative bases with fractional exponents and prevents overflow.
11
12    Mathematical Definition:
13        safe_power(b, e) = sign(b) * |b|^e  for negative b
14                         = b^e              for non-negative b
15        where b is clipped to |b| ≥ epsilon and e is clipped to |e| ≤ max_exp
16
17    Args:
18        base: Base value(s) (scalar or array)
19        exponent: Exponent value(s) (scalar or array)
20        epsilon: Minimum base magnitude (default: 1e-15)
21        max_exp: Maximum exponent magnitude (default: 700.0)
22        warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)
23
24    Returns:
25        Safe power with same shape as inputs (after broadcasting)
26
27    Example:
28        >>> safe_power(2.0, 3.0)
29        8.0
30        >>> safe_power(-2.0, 3.0)  # Negative base
31        -8.0
32        >>> safe_power(1e-20, 2.0)  # Small base protected
33        1e-30
34        >>> safe_power(np.array([2, -2, 1e-20]), 2.0)
35        array([4.0e+00, 4.0e+00, 1.0e-30])
36
37    Notes:
38        - Handles negative bases by: (-b)^e = sign(-b) * |b|^e
39        - Protects small bases to prevent underflow
40        - Clips large exponents to prevent overflow
41        - Use for robust polynomial and power-law calculations
42    """
43    base_array = np.asarray(base, dtype=float)
44    exp_array = np.asarray(exponent, dtype=float)
45
46    # Handle negative bases
47    abs_base = np.abs(base_array)
48    sign_base = np.sign(base_array)
49    sign_base[sign_base == 0] = 1.0  # Treat zero as positive
50
51    # Protect small bases
52    safe_base = np.maximum(abs_base, epsilon)
53
54    # Clip exponents to prevent overflow
55    safe_exp = np.clip(exp_array, -max_exp, max_exp)
56
57    # Compute power with absolute base
58    result = np.power(safe_base, safe_exp)
59
60    # Apply sign for negative bases (sign^exp pattern)
61    # For integer exponents: (-b)^n = b^n if n even, -b^n if n odd
62    # For fractional exponents: use principal value (real part)
63    is_integer_exp = np.equal(np.mod(exp_array, 1), 0)
64    is_odd_exp = np.logical_and(is_integer_exp, np.mod(exp_array, 2) != 0)
65
66    # Apply sign only for odd integer exponents
67    result = np.where(is_odd_exp, result * sign_base, result)
68
69    if warn:
70        small_base_mask = abs_base < epsilon
71        large_exp_mask = np.abs(exp_array) > max_exp
72        if np.any(small_base_mask):
73            warnings.warn(
74                f"Protected {np.sum(small_base_mask)} small bases with epsilon",
75                RuntimeWarning,
76                stacklevel=2,
77            )
78        if np.any(large_exp_mask):
79            warnings.warn(
80                f"Clipped {np.sum(large_exp_mask)} large exponents",
81                RuntimeWarning,
82                stacklevel=2,
83            )
84
85    # Return scalar if inputs were scalar
86    if np.isscalar(base) and np.isscalar(exponent):
87        return float(result.item() if hasattr(result, 'item') else result)
88    return result

safe_norm(vector, ord, axis, min_norm)¶

Safe vector/matrix norm with zero-norm protection.

Computes norm with minimum threshold to prevent zero division in normalization operations.

Mathematical Definition: safe_norm(v) = max(||v||_p, min_norm)

where ||·||_p is the p-norm.

Args: vector: Input array (vector or matrix) ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean norm) - 1: L1 norm (sum of absolute values) - 2: L2 norm (Euclidean) - np.inf: L∞ norm (maximum absolute value) axis: Axis along which to compute norm (default: None = flatten) min_norm: Minimum norm value (default: 1e-15)

Returns: Norm value(s) with minimum threshold applied

Example: >>> safe_norm(np.array([3, 4])) 5.0 >>> safe_norm(np.array([1e-20, 1e-20])) 1e-15 >>> safe_norm(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 1]]), axis=1) array([1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+00])

Notes: - Used to protect normalization: v / ||v|| becomes v / safe_norm(v) - min_norm should match expected numerical precision of application - Preserves norm semantics while preventing degenerate cases

Source Code¶

 1def safe_norm(
 2    vector: np.ndarray,
 3    ord: Optional[Union[int, float, str]] = 2,
 4    axis: Optional[int] = None,
 5    min_norm: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
 6) -> Union[float, np.ndarray]:
 7    """Safe vector/matrix norm with zero-norm protection.
 8
 9    Computes norm with minimum threshold to prevent zero division in
10    normalization operations.
11
12    Mathematical Definition:
13        safe_norm(v) = max(||v||_p, min_norm)
14
15    where ||·||_p is the p-norm.
16
17    Args:
18        vector: Input array (vector or matrix)
19        ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean norm)
20             - 1: L1 norm (sum of absolute values)
21             - 2: L2 norm (Euclidean)
22             - np.inf: L∞ norm (maximum absolute value)
23        axis: Axis along which to compute norm (default: None = flatten)
24        min_norm: Minimum norm value (default: 1e-15)
25
26    Returns:
27        Norm value(s) with minimum threshold applied
28
29    Example:
30        >>> safe_norm(np.array([3, 4]))
31        5.0
32        >>> safe_norm(np.array([1e-20, 1e-20]))
33        1e-15
34        >>> safe_norm(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 1]]), axis=1)
35        array([1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+00])
36
37    Notes:
38        - Used to protect normalization: v / ||v|| becomes v / safe_norm(v)
39        - min_norm should match expected numerical precision of application
40        - Preserves norm semantics while preventing degenerate cases
41    """
42    norm_value = np.linalg.norm(vector, ord=ord, axis=axis)
43    return np.maximum(norm_value, min_norm)

safe_normalize(vector, ord, axis, min_norm, fallback)¶

Safe vector normalization with zero-norm protection.

Normalizes vector to unit norm with protection against zero-length vectors.

Mathematical Definition: safe_normalize(v) = v / max(||v||, min_norm)

Args: vector: Input vector(s) to normalize ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean) axis: Normalization axis (default: None = flatten) min_norm: Minimum norm threshold (default: 1e-15) fallback: Value to return for zero vectors (default: zeros)

Returns: Normalized vector with same shape as input

Example: >>> safe_normalize(np.array([3, 4])) array([0.6, 0.8]) >>> safe_normalize(np.array([0, 0])) array([0., 0.]) >>> safe_normalize(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 2]]), axis=1) array([[1., 0.], [0., 1.]])

Notes: - For zero vectors, returns fallback (default: zero vector) - Use in gradient descent, direction finding, unit vector generation - Preserves direction while guaranteeing unit magnitude

Source Code¶

 1def safe_normalize(
 2    vector: np.ndarray,
 3    ord: Optional[Union[int, float, str]] = 2,
 4    axis: Optional[int] = None,
 5    min_norm: float = EPSILON_SQRT,
 6    fallback: Optional[np.ndarray] = None,
 7) -> np.ndarray:
 8    """Safe vector normalization with zero-norm protection.
 9
10    Normalizes vector to unit norm with protection against zero-length vectors.
11
12    Mathematical Definition:
13        safe_normalize(v) = v / max(||v||, min_norm)
14
15    Args:
16        vector: Input vector(s) to normalize
17        ord: Norm order (default: 2 for Euclidean)
18        axis: Normalization axis (default: None = flatten)
19        min_norm: Minimum norm threshold (default: 1e-15)
20        fallback: Value to return for zero vectors (default: zeros)
21
22    Returns:
23        Normalized vector with same shape as input
24
25    Example:
26        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([3, 4]))
27        array([0.6, 0.8])
28        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([0, 0]))
29        array([0., 0.])
30        >>> safe_normalize(np.array([[1, 0], [0, 2]]), axis=1)
31        array([[1., 0.],
32               [0., 1.]])
33
34    Notes:
35        - For zero vectors, returns fallback (default: zero vector)
36        - Use in gradient descent, direction finding, unit vector generation
37        - Preserves direction while guaranteeing unit magnitude
38    """
39    vector_array = np.asarray(vector, dtype=float)
40
41    # Compute safe norm
42    norm_value = safe_norm(vector_array, ord=ord, axis=axis, min_norm=min_norm)
43
44    # Expand norm dimensions for broadcasting if needed
45    if axis is not None and vector_array.ndim > 1:
46        norm_value = np.expand_dims(norm_value, axis=axis)
47
48    # Normalize with safe division
49    normalized = vector_array / norm_value
50
51    # Handle exactly zero vectors with fallback
52    is_zero = np.linalg.norm(vector_array, ord=ord, axis=axis) < min_norm
53    if fallback is not None and np.any(is_zero):
54        if axis is not None:
55            is_zero = np.expand_dims(is_zero, axis=axis)
56        normalized = np.where(is_zero, fallback, normalized)
57
58    return normalized

is_safe_denominator(denominator, epsilon)¶

Check if denominator is safe for division (|x| >= epsilon).

Args: denominator: Value(s) to check epsilon: Safety threshold (default: 1e-12)

Returns: Boolean or boolean array indicating safety

Example: >>> is_safe_denominator(1.0) True >>> is_safe_denominator(1e-15) False >>> is_safe_denominator(np.array([1, 1e-15, -2])) array([ True, False, True])

Source Code¶

 1def is_safe_denominator(
 2    denominator: NumericType,
 3    epsilon: float = EPSILON_DIV,
 4) -> Union[bool, np.ndarray]:
 5    """Check if denominator is safe for division (|x| >= epsilon).
 6
 7    Args:
 8        denominator: Value(s) to check
 9        epsilon: Safety threshold (default: 1e-12)
10
11    Returns:
12        Boolean or boolean array indicating safety
13
14    Example:
15        >>> is_safe_denominator(1.0)
16        True
17        >>> is_safe_denominator(1e-15)
18        False
19        >>> is_safe_denominator(np.array([1, 1e-15, -2]))
20        array([ True, False,  True])
21    """
22    den_array = np.asarray(denominator, dtype=float)
23    is_safe = np.abs(den_array) >= epsilon
24
25    if np.isscalar(denominator):
26        return bool(is_safe)
27    return is_safe

clip_to_safe_range(x, min_value, max_value, warn)¶

Clip values to safe numerical range to prevent overflow/underflow.

Args: x: Input value(s) min_value: Minimum safe value (default: -1e10) max_value: Maximum safe value (default: 1e10) warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)

Returns: Clipped values with same shape as input

Example: >>> clip_to_safe_range(1e15) 10000000000.0 >>> clip_to_safe_range(np.array([-1e12, 0, 1e12])) array([-1.0e+10, 0.0e+00, 1.0e+10])

Source Code¶

 1def clip_to_safe_range(
 2    x: NumericType,
 3    min_value: float = -1e10,
 4    max_value: float = 1e10,
 5    warn: bool = False,
 6) -> NumericType:
 7    """Clip values to safe numerical range to prevent overflow/underflow.
 8
 9    Args:
10        x: Input value(s)
11        min_value: Minimum safe value (default: -1e10)
12        max_value: Maximum safe value (default: 1e10)
13        warn: Warn if clipping occurs (default: False)
14
15    Returns:
16        Clipped values with same shape as input
17
18    Example:
19        >>> clip_to_safe_range(1e15)
20        10000000000.0
21        >>> clip_to_safe_range(np.array([-1e12, 0, 1e12]))
22        array([-1.0e+10,  0.0e+00,  1.0e+10])
23    """
24    x_array = np.asarray(x, dtype=float)
25    clipped = np.clip(x_array, min_value, max_value)
26
27    if warn:
28        num_clipped = np.sum(x_array != clipped)
29        if num_clipped > 0:
30            warnings.warn(
31                f"Clipped {num_clipped} values to range [{min_value}, {max_value}]",
32                RuntimeWarning,
33                stacklevel=2,
34            )
35
36    if np.isscalar(x):
37        return float(clipped)
38    return clipped
